body_html:
• Paths are now absolute
  • I added a comment about std::array vs c10::array (basically, use c10::array for compile time programming, use either for runtime programming). I could have called it c10::constexpr_array or something like that to make it more clear, but since it's actually just a std::array with a few improvements (and std::array in C++14/C++17 is actually constexpr), I thought I'd call it correspondingly.
  • .cpp files that only include one .h file and don't do anything else have two reasons for existing:
    • It forces the header file to not have dependencies it doesn't declare (include-what-you-use)
    • It offers a place for the compiler to fail and show error messages for the header itself instead of only through (possibly more complex) dependent code
body_text:
Paths are now absolute
I added a comment about std::array vs c10::array (basically, use c10::array for compile time programming, use either for runtime programming). I could have called it c10::constexpr_array or something like that to make it more clear, but since it's actually just a std::array with a few improvements (and std::array in C++14/C++17 is actually constexpr), I thought I'd call it correspondingly.
.cpp files that only include one .h file and don't do anything else have two reasons for existing:

It forces the header file to not have dependencies it doesn't declare (include-what-you-use)
It offers a place for the compiler to fail and show error messages for the header itself instead of only through (possibly more complex) dependent code
body:
- Paths are now absolute
- I added a comment about std::array vs c10::array (basically, use c10::array for compile time programming, use either for runtime programming). I could have called it c10::constexpr_array or something like that to make it more clear, but since it's actually just a std::array with a few improvements (and std::array in C++14/C++17 is actually constexpr), I thought I'd call it correspondingly.
- .cpp files that only include one .h file and don't do anything else have two reasons for existing:
  - It forces the header file to not have dependencies it doesn't declare (include-what-you-use)
  - It offers a place for the compiler to fail and show error messages for the header itself instead of only through (possibly more complex) dependent code
